description: Iceland announced the closing of upper secondary schools and universities starting March 16th. Preschools and elementary schools will be place under special conditions.

description: Iceland announced the closing of upper secondary schools and universities starting March 16th. Preschools and elementary schools will be place under special conditions.

description: On May 4, the gathering ban will be raised to 50 individuals. Preschools and elementary schools, which have operated at a limited capacity, will resume regular operation, and junior colleges and universities will reopen. All schools must limit student groups according to the 50-person limit. UPDATE: On May 4th preschools and elementry schools will resume regular operation and junior colleges and universities will reopen
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)

description: The national commissioner of the Icelandic police raises the alert level of the response to COVID-19 to emergency phase on March 6th, following the confirmation of the first transmissions of the virus within Iceland.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: The national commissioner of the Icelandic police raises the alert level of the response to COVID-19 to emergency phase on March 6th, following the confirmation of the first transmissions of the virus within Iceland. The national emergency rating was lowered on May 25. UPDATE: The national emergency rating was lowered on May 25
type_sub_cat: NA

description: In Iceland from June 15th, tourists will be able to provide a health certificate or opt for a coronavirus screening at Keflavik airport, instead of completing a two-week quarantine.
type_sub_cat: Visa extensions (e.g. visa validity extended)

description: In Iceland from June 15th, tourists will be able to provide a health certificate or opt for a coronavirus screening at Keflavik airport, instead of completing a two-week quarantine. Starting on July 16th, passengers arriving in Iceland from Norway, Denmark, Finland and Germany will no longer need to get screen for the novel coronavirus nor go into quarantine upon arriving in Iceland, provided they have been in these countries for at least 14 days UPDATE: Starting on July 16th, passengers arriving in Iceland from Norway, Denmark, Finland and Germany will no longer need to get screen for the novel coronavirus nor go into quarantine upon arriving in Iceland, provided they have been in these countries for at least 14 days
type_sub_cat: Visa extensions (e.g. visa validity extended)

description:
In Iceland, from July 13th, for Icelandic residents and citizens returning home have to on arrival complete a period of “heimkomusmitgát” (home-coming contagion caution). This means will they be tested for COVID-19 at the border and they will also be required to undergo a second free PCR test at a local healthcare centre four to five days later. Until they get the results of the second test Icelanders should:

Maintain two-metre distancing
Only attend gatherings of up to ten people
Avoid high-risk individuals e.g. the elderly
Avoid physical contact

Heimkomusmitgát is not the same as quarantine; Icelanders will be  permitted to use public transport, go to shops and meet family and friends whilst they await test results.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: Iceland launched a tracing app on April 1 to track potential Covid-19 infections.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: Icelandic health authorities have in cooperation with the medical research company deCode Genetics undertaken for the COVID-19 virus among the Icelandic population since the 13th of March.
type_sub_cat: NA
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Iceland allows everyone to be tested for the corona virus.
type_sub_cat: NA
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Icelands Chief Epidemiologist and deCODE Genetics start collecting blood samples from the general public in order to help determine how widespread COVID-19 infection has been within the Icelandic population on May 4. Donating blood for the survey is voluntarily. People undergoing blood tests for other reasons will also be asked to donate a sample. The blood samples will also be tested for antibodies. Those, who give blood will be notified of their test results.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: As of May 12, Icelands Directory of Health announced that blood samples for anti body tests for Covid-19 are only collected from individuals who come in for blood tests for other reasons. UPDATE: Originally blood samples should be taken from volunteers, now samples are only collected from individuals who come in for blood tests for other reasons.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: Iceland launches website on March 13 that informs about Covid-19 containing what one need or want to know about the virus, including how to protect oneself, how Iceland is responding, and special information for tourists
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The State of Iceland rents the Fosshotel Lind in Reykjavík it will be converted into a quarantine for tourists and others, unable to be in quarantine at home during the COVID-19 pandemic.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: Change in who the policy applies towards - quarantine used to only apply to certaun high risk areas, whereas it now applies to all areas outside of Iceland.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: Iceland is enforcing a 14-day quarantine is for all residents of Iceland entering the countrystarting March 19th. UPDATE: Change in who the policy applies towards - quarantine used to only apply to certain high risk areas, whereas it now applies to all areas outside of Iceland
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: Iceland announced fines between £360-3590 for violations of the 14-day mandatory quarantine, starting from the 29th of March
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: The chief epidemiologist of Iceland implemented isolation for all persons who are ill with COVID-19 or suspected to have the virus from the 13th of March.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: Iceland enforced a two-week quarantine on all tourists arriving in the country starting on May 24th. UPDATE: Originally only Icelanders and residents of Iceland had to go into quarantine after arriving in the country. Starting with April 24th tourists are no longer exempt from this rule.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: Iceland closes the "Fosshotel Lind", which was used as a quarantine station for tourists and others unable to be in quarantine at home during the COVID-19 pandemic. The last guests checked out on May 14. UPDATE: The "Fosshotel Lind" which was used as a quarantine station has been closed. The last guests checked out on May 14.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: The State of Iceland rents the Fosshotel Lind in Reykjavík it will be converted into a quarantine for tourists and others, unable to be in quarantine at home during the COVID-19 pandemic. The quarantine house closed on May 18th. UPDATE: The quarantine house closed on May 18th
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: Iceland sets ut guidelines for restaurants and tour operators from March 14. Restaurants were asked to re-arrange their seating to at least two meters between seats, asking that only families and other groups in regular close contact would be seated together, that menus would be washed between each use, and that hand sanitation be available at entry and encourage guests to use them. Tour operators have been asked to offer hand sanitiser at every entry point and encourage passengers to use them, to use back doors if available, make sure that passengers embark and disembark with enough space in between each, and skip using every other row to ensure proper space between passengers.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: Iceland government announced that from March 24 to April 12 grocery stores and drug stores are allowed to have maximum 100  people in the stores, as long as a distance of 2 meters between people can be ensured.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: Iceland ordered the closure of swimming pools, gyms, bars, clubs, slot machines and museums starting on March 23. Operations and services that require close contact between individuals or risk close contact are also prohibited. This includes sports clubs, hairdressers, beauty salons, and massage parlours.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: Iceland government announced that from March 24 to April 12 grocery stores and drug stores are allowed to have maximum 100  people in the stores, as long as a distance of 2 meters between people can be ensured. Iceland government announced that the ban of over 100 people in the stores will continue. UPDATE: Iceland government announced on April 14 that the maximum of 100 people in grocery stores and pharmacies will continue.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: Iceland allowed dentist’s offices, physiotherapy clinics, hairdressers and massage parlours to reopen on May 4. UPDATE: Dentist’s offices, physiotherapy clinics, hairdressers and massage parlours are allowed to reopen on May 4.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: Iceland allowed public swimming pools to reopen on May 18. UPDATE: Swimming pools reopen on May 18.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: Iceland allows bars and restaurants to be open but they must close by 11pm from May 25.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: The Nauthólsvík Beach (Iceland) reopens on May 25. The hot tub may remain closed for some time. The reason is that, unlike hot tubs at swimming pools, this one has no chlorine in it. UPDATE: The Nauthólsvík Beach reopens on May 25.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: Iceland announce that from August 5 the number of people allowed at swimming pools and bathing places is reverted back to the ruling from earlier this summer. That means that the number of guests may never exceed half of the maximum number of guests allowed under the operating license. Children born in 2015 and later are not included in this number. This is valid until August 13.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: Iceland announced that From august 5 Supermarkets over a thousand square meters in size may allow a maximum of 200 customers in total. Smaller supermarkets may accommodate up to 100 people at a time, provided that the conditions for distance limits are met. The changes are valid until August 13th.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: Iceland government announced that from March 24 to April 12 grocery stores and drug stores are allowed to have maximum 100  people in the stores, as long as a distance of 2 meters between people can be ensured. From august 5 Supermarkets over a thousand square meters in size may allow a maximum of 200 customers in total. Smaller supermarkets may accommodate up to 100 people at a time, provided that the conditions for distance limits are met. The changes are valid until August 13th. UPDATE: Supermarkets over a thousand square meters in size may allow a maximum of 200 customers in total from august 5
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: The Icelandic government announced a ban on gatherings of more than 100 entering into force on the 16th of March.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: The Icelandic government modified the number of people allowed at gatherings from 100 to 20 starting on the 24th of March. UPDATE: The limit of people at getherings has been changed from 100 to 20
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: The Icelandic government has announce fines of up to $360 for those violating the 20 people gathering ban starting from the 29th of March UPDATE: The 20 people limit of gathering is now being enforced through fines
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Iceland prolongs the ban on gatherings over 20 people and the closure of schools from April 13 to May 4. UPDATE: Iceland prolongs ban on gatherings and closures of schools from the 13th of April to the 4th of May.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Iceland modified the number of people allowed at gatherings from 20 to 50 starting on May 4th. UPDATE: The Icelandic government modified the number of people allowed at gatherings from 20 to 50 starting on the 4th of May.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: The Icelandic government raised the number of people allowed at gatherings from 50 to 200, starting at May 24. UPDATE: Instead of the current limit of 50 people on a gathering Iceland rises the number up to 200 people at gatherings, starting at May 24.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Iceland cancel The Sailors’ Day celebrations in Reykjavik, the event was due to be held on June 7th.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: The Icelandic government announced a ban on gatherings of more than 100 entering into force on the 16th of March. The maximum number of people allowed to gather indoors has increased from 200 to 500 people from June 15th to July 5. UPDATE: The maximum number of people allowed to gather indoors has increased from 200 to 500 people from June 15th.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: The Icelandic government announced a ban on gatherings of more than 100 entering into force on the 16th of March.  From July 31 gatherings of over 100 people will be banned, this applies to all public spaces, including shops. Children born after 2005 are exempt from this rule. The ban is expected to last until August 13. UPDATE: From July 31 gatherings of over 100 people will be banned instead of 200
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Iceland cancels a number of events and festivities over Merchant’s weekend that takes place August 4 to August 6. This as a response to the new COVID-19 restrictions in Iceland, such as Einnar með allur in Akureyri, Sæludaga in Vatnaskógur and Innipúkinn in Reykjavík. Pride, the Skjaldborg Festival in Patreksfjörður and Þjóðhátíð, the annual outdoor festival held in Vestmannaeyjar, have likewise been canceled.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Iceland announced that from August 5 to August 13  there will be no permits given for any sort of entertainment gatherings/events which can be expected to attract groups of people after 23:00.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: The festival Culture Night in Reykjavík, Iceland, has been canceled this year due to Covid-19. The event was supposed to take place on August 22.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description:
The Icelandic government announced on September 4 that the maximum number of guests permitted at any one time in swimming pools, bathing
facilities and fitness centres will be raised from 50% to 75% of the numbers permitted under their operating licences. This will come into effect September 7 2020. UPDATE: The previous maximum number of guests permitted in swimming pools, bathing facilities and fitness centers will be raised from 50% to 75% capacity.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description:
The Icelandic government announced a ban on gatherings of more than 100 entering into force on the 16th of March.
UPDATE: The Icelandic government has increased the limitations on mass gatherings from 100 to 200 people, entering into force on the 7th of September 2020. UPDATE: The maximum size of gatherings will be increased from 100 to 200 people on Monday, 7 September 2020.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: The City of Reykjavík offers short-term emergency houses to those who lost their housing due to Covid-19 crisis. This service will be in operation for four months. The emergency housing will be available to people regardless of their legal domicile. They will be allowed to stay in the short-term housing until their case has been channelled to the municipality in which they live.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: Iceland announce that from July 31 wearing masks will be mandatory on public transport, including planes and ferries. This is expected to be in place until August 13th. The ministry of Health stated on August 5 that face masks shall be used in public transport if the journey lasts longer than thirty minutes. This is expected to be in place until August 13th UPDATE: The first announcement said that you have to wear a face mask when you use  public transport, now you only have to wear a face mask at public transport if the ride is longer than 30 minutes.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description:
Iceland announces that people will have to keep a distance of 2 meters in common areas starting from the 24th of March.
UPDATE: The Icelandic government announces that the original 2 metre social distancing rule has been relaxed to 1 metre. This will take affect on September 7. UPDATE: The ‘social distancing’ rule will be relaxed from the original 2 metre distance to 1 metre.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
